meeting_annotations.speaker: Andrea Hicks
meeting_annotations.transcript: Oh yeah sorry so the I was thinking bacteria scale. Yeah aquaponics you see economies of scale. So the bigger your operation is the more environmentally or less environmentally impactful they are and the more economical they are. And I think one of the points that someone brought up is really novel is it's they're more interesting in areas where it's really hard to produce food because you can do it either in an urban environment or in a remote location. So like in some of the more remote villages in Hawaii they've got a lot of these systems where it's just really expensive environmentally and economically to bring food to the villages.

And then if the CO2 is sourced from direct air capture you're right like forget about the hydrogen for a second that's at best circular. You know because you're putting the CO2 into the chemical forget about the energy flows and the material flows and the carbon intensity just assume they're neutral you burn the fuel and the CO2 goes back into the atmosphere so it's at best circular right or neutral. meeting_annotations.speaker: Jennifer Wilcox
meeting_annotations.transcript: So in that case the hydrogen again is is comes in at best neutral. CO2 is from air the carbon goes back into the air that's not negative that's at best neutral. The only way to actually be negative is to pull the carbon out of the atmosphere and remove it not put it back. So if the hydrogen is sourced from biomass waste and the carbon associated with that hydrogen in that pyrolysis process is stored which many wouldn't want to do like the companies today are like why would I do that I'm making a syngas I'm making a fuel I'm making a biofuel. But in if you would like to achieve a carbon negative fuel that is really the only pathway to doing it. Everything else is really just carbon neutral at best. So it's tricky but it does have the co-benefit of not depending on crude oil which we've talked about.
